title: Developing the Aerobic System
content: Phil explains the importance of developing the aerobic system, defines maximum aerobic function (MAF), and explains how to determine your MAF heart rate. He then demonstrates how to integrate that into a training protocol which is designed to help people move faster at a sub maximum heart rate and increase fat utilization as the primary source of fuel—emphasizing the importance of nutrition on one’s capacity to oxidize fat.

title: Training Insights from World-Class Marathoners
content: Phil extracts training insights from the amazing feats of world-class marathoners, explores the impact of a low-carb diet on one’s capacity for high intensity exercise and anaerobic performance, and explains the downstream effects of being “overfat”.

title: Training insights from a six-day race
content: Phil’s background in running, and training insights from a six-day race (2:30);

title: The difference between being “fit” and being “healthy”
content: The difference between being “fit” and being “healthy” (11:00);

title: Defining the aerobic and anaerobic systems
content: Defining the aerobic and anaerobic systems, and why VO2 max doesn’t predict performance (18:15);

title: Defining maximum aerobic function (MAF)
content: Defining maximum aerobic function (MAF), determining your MAF heart rate with Phil’s 180 Formula, and why a strong aerobic system is crucial to health and performance (24:00);

title: Using the MAF test to track and improve your aerobic fitness
content: Using the MAF test to track and improve your aerobic fitness (37:30);

title: The impact of nutrition on one’s ability to use fat as fuel while exercising
content: The impact of nutrition on one’s ability to use fat as fuel while exercising (43:00);

content: Assessing the impact of a low-carb diet on high intensity exercise and anaerobic performance (58:00);

title: Physiology of a stress response
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more. He also provides insight into the factors that contribute to the stress response (and our ability to handle it) such as social rank, personality, environment, and genetics.

title: Individual variation in the response to stress
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses how everyone has a different optimal level of stress response and how social rank and personality differences affect our stress response.

title: Tips for managing stress in the modern world
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., provides tips for managing stress in the modern world.

title: The impact of stress on cancer, atherosclerosis, dementia, addiction, and depression
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the impact of stress on cancer, atherosclerosis, dementia, addiction, and depression.

title: Insights from a Six-Day Race
content: Phil has been running since high school and college. He progressed to the marathon culminating in running a six day race. The six day race is a race where you run around a track and the person who accumulates the most miles or kilometers is the winner. Phil discovered the optimal strategy is to start the race by walking, gradually pick up the pace, start jogging, until you hit your maximum aerobic heart rate. There’s no hard running at all during the race, no high heart rate, no high intensity training needed. Sleep takes a back seat during the race — sometimes even taken very small naps as short as 7 minutes.

title: The Difference Between Being 'Fit' and Being 'Healthy'
content: Phil started seeing many amateur athletes who were getting injured. He gradually started seeing more advanced athletes through referrals to the point where many professionals runners were coming to him. By the mid 1980s, Phil had seen professional athletes in all sports, and that was the majority of his patients. Phil realized something was wrong with the way athletes were training/competing when he began seeing how someone could run a marathon at an incredible pace — and the thought was “wow, what an example of optimal health!” However, it wasn’t exactly the case — they were broken down, they were getting sick.

title: The Relationship Between Being Healthy and Being Fit
content: Phil began having a hard time delineating between the relationship between being healthy and being fit. He has an epiphany after he ran the New York City Marathon in 1980. When he crossed the finish line, a lightbulb went off —“These athletes are fit but unhealthy”. From that experience, Phil began thinking about the average person. He developed the MAF test, for example, for the average person (not just the athlete).

title: Defining the Aerobic and Anaerobic Systems, and Why VO2 Max Doesn’t Predict Performance
content: What do we mean by aerobic and anaerobic systems? Aerobic system: Fat burning is associated with aerobic. All of the factors that are associated with fat burning—the aerobic muscle fibers, the mitochondria, and the ability to convert fatty acids into energy (ATP). Anaerobic system: Using glucose (rather than fat) for making ATP. Phil uses heart rate to determine whether you’re drifting into that anaerobic state. Therefore, if you stay under a certain HR, you’re in an aerobic state. Despite common belief, VO2 max is not a great predictor of much. The research actually says that you can’t predict marathon finish time by VO2 max. But people don’t like hearing that because they have this idea that VO2 max is directly associated with performance. They think they need to rev up their VO2 max by doing hard training, which will get them performing better, and that’s where the whole system breaks down.

title: Maximum Aerobic Function
content: MAF stands for maximum aerobic function. In essence, the goal of being healthy and fit is to develop the aerobic system, says Phil. Why is developing the aerobic system the goal? This is what our ancestors did—we developed a really incredibly powerful aerobic system by doing the things in our lifestyle that drive that aerobic system to develop.

title: Developing the Concept of Maximum Aerobic Heart Rate
content: While studying anthropology in college, Phil began to wonder why are we doing all this “other stuff” in modern day. “The concept of max aerobic function has been really with me for quite some time.” When he started working with runners, he began talking about the pace that these athletes could run at a given “aerobic heart rate” which he called, “maximum aerobic heart rate”. An individual’s maximum aerobic heart rate was originally derived with a combination of a physical exam in his (history, lab work, posture, strength, etc.); and observing the person on a track. Phil would assign them a MAF heart rate and have them go and train. He would test them again to see if it correlated.

title: Phil’s 180 Formula
content: A person is going to be at their maximum aerobic output—meaning they’re going to be maximally fat oxidizing—at an approximate heart rate of 180 minus their age, plus or minus a few modifications. You begin with 180 minus your age and individualize it to your health and fitness needs. For example, you would subtract 10 from your number if: You’re recovering from an illness, You’re severely overtrained, You’re in rehab from an injury, You’re on medication. You would subtract 5 from your number if: You have asthma, You are a bit overfat, You haven’t exercised consistently in a while. You can ADD 5 to your number if: You’re a competitive athlete with no health problems.

title: Overtraining and MAF Training
content: Phil found that many of his athletes were overtraining and could perform better with less training at a lower intensity. He became obsessed with building the best aerobic system and noticed that traditional interval training did not improve performance at the same heart rate, while MAF training did. MAF training involves determining your MAF heart rate and trying to improve your performance at that heart rate over time to become more aerobically fit and efficient.

title: Using the MAF Test to Improve Aerobic Fitness
content: The MAF test involves determining your MAF heart rate and trying to improve your performance at that heart rate over time. By staying at the same heart rate and improving your pace, you become more aerobically fit and efficient. Phil recommends staying at the same heart rate rather than adjusting it up, as cheating up may not lead to long-term improvements. It takes three to six months to hit a plateau with MAF training.

title: Increasing Sub-Max Pace to Improve Maximum Pace
content: Improving your sub-max pace at a given heart rate can lead to improvements in your maximum pace. Phil notes that top runners in a 10k race likely finish well above their MAF target pace, but they may still be able to cover greater distances at their MAF heart rate than other runners they beat in the race. Sub-max performance predicts maximum performance, so it's important to push your MAF protocol even if you're training for a race at a pace above your MAF level.

title: Fat Burning Potential
content: Peter talks about how much fat burning is needed during exercise and how athletes on a low-carb diet can hit up to 2.2 grams of fat per minute. Phil also came to the same conclusion that lower-intensity training and lower-carb eating impacted people’s capacity to burn fat.

title: Nutrition and Fat Oxidation
content: Peter talks about how his switch to a strict ketogenic diet allowed him to hit a fat oxidation of 1.73 grams per minute during VO2 max testing. Phil also talks about how nutrition impacts fat oxidation potential and how many of the subjects in studies were big carbohydrate eaters that distorted the research completely.

title: Carbohydrate Intolerance
content: Phil talks about his nutritional approach with patients and the concept of 'carbohydrate intolerance' which he uses to coach individuals on the idea of carbohydrate tolerance. He also mentions how we all become more insulin resistant as the years go by.

title: Holistic Approach to Health
content: Holism is the idea that all systems are connected and work in conjunction with each other. And more specific to his patients, holism means weaving together exercise, nutrition and stress management.

title: The Two-Week Test
content: Phil came up with a challenge for his patients called the Two-Week Test. Essentially, for two weeks, the patient removes all the junk food from their diet, and also cuts way down on the natural carbohydrates like lentils and beans and rice and fruits. After the two weeks, you looks at their symptoms and see if any are better. And in Phils experience, he says about 75% of people get better. Next, you begin to add things back into the diet carefully to see at what point things start to trigger the bad symptoms again. Phil points out the importance of enlisting the patient in the process: “I want them to use their instincts and intuition to understand what it feels like to eat too much carbohydrate before you’ve gotten there.”

title: Low-Carb Diet and Exercise Performance
content: Peter spent several years on a very low carbohydrate diet and saw enormous improvements in my aerobic fitness. His anaerobic fitness (higher level intensity fitness), did not deteriorate, but it took a very long time for that to come around. However, a study that Phil was part of found something different. A 4-week study that put recreationally trained athletes on a very low carbohydrate diet. Performance remained similar between groups, but the very low carb, high fat (VLCHF) group ended up with higher mean and peak fat oxidation. Conclusion: very low carbohydrate intake did not deteriorate high-intensity performance.

title: The MAF Test and Training Progress
content: The MAF test is a tool that helps people track their progress in exercising at their MAF HR. Knowing HR is crucial. Every once in a while, an athlete might know exactly how to run at that max fat-burning level, but it’s uncommon. For most people, we are in a ‘no pain, no gain’ world, and we’re seeing injuries.

title: Insights from World-Class Marathoners
content: Phil Maffetone's 2014 book: 1:59: The Sub-Two-Hour Marathon Is Within Reach—Here’s How It Will Go Down, and What It Can Teach All Runners about Training and Racing. In October of 2019, Eliud Kipchoge broke the 2-hour mark: Breaking2. It wasn’t recognized as official as it was sort of a contrived example of what could be done under the most optimal conditions. That said, there’s simply no denying that what Kipchoge did was unbelievable. In the 2018 Berlin Marathon, Kipchoge got very close in an official race with a time of 2:01:39 — the official world record.

title: Phil's Thoughts on Breaking the 2-Hour Barrier
content: Phil knew that someone would eventually break the 2-hour barrier. He considered various factors like wearing lighter shoes, being lighter, body type, and being a better fat burner. He was working with runners starting to hit five-minute pace for their MAF test. He thinks that if optimally trained, a Kenyan athlete could break the two-hour marathon barrier in a real race.

title: Marathoner's Prime and Longevity
content: Many of the top marathoners tend to be from places like Kenya and they are doing it to break out of poverty. They end up burning out. Many world-class marathoners acknowledge they might only have a dozen marathons in them in their entire career where they’re going to really be able to run at a certain level.

title: The Philosophy of Endurance Training
content: If they were to spread those 12 marathons over 15 years, that’s a different philosophy than the “churn and burn” philosophy. Meb Keflezighi won the Boston Marathon in his late 30s. Kipchoge is in his mid-30s. In Phil’s book, he writes about the makeup of a 1:59 marathoner. Someone who is in their 30s. Not somebody who could run a great 10K (anymore) but certainly could have been great in their 20s. But now in their 30s and even early 40s, they will have built a great endurance base — “now they’ve got the best of everything”.

title: The Overfat Condition
content: How being “overfat” affects health and performance, and ways to decrease excess body fat. The term “overfat”. See Phil’s paper: Overfat and Underfat: New Terms and Definitions Long Overdue. Phil is not fond of the term overweight, and prefers overfat. It’s adipose tissue we should be concerned with, not mass. Phil’s published a few papers in 2017 (here, here, and here) on the usage of “overfat” and “underfat”. Waist circumference and waist to height ratio are suggested as a better indicators of metabolic health than BMI. Phil and his co-author estimated the prevalence of overfat to be 91% in US adults and 69% in US children; Obesity is leveling off, but increases in abdominal fat are not.

title: The Effects of Overfatness on Health and Performance
content: How is society’s trend of overfatness affecting health and performance? They’re related in terms of terms of the diminishing performance of age group athletes, says Phil. The overfat condition can typically add weight to the body, so that’s going to affect running performance. But more significantly, those people with excess body fat have some downstream problems that can be very serious. Blood fat abnormalities, blood sugar abnormalities, blood pressure abnormalities, and ultimately chronic illness. In that situation, people are obviously not going to be performing their best. People with excess body fat also have physical impairment problems more frequently.

title: Reducing Excess Body Fat
content: Why isn’t more emphasis being put on reducing excess body fat? Peter’s take is that people are starting to acknowledge this but it always takes longer to spread through society. For example, sugar consumption is actually declining, but it sometimes takes awhile for this decline to necessarily translate into some of the health benefits. Furthermore, these things are so multifaceted. For example, activity levels might be declining even while certain elements of nutrition improve, and so the net effect of that could be a reduction. E.g., Quality of sleep could be declining, and that can offset any benefit that we see. Phil’s message around that: 1-Start with walking. All a deconditioned person needs to do is start by walking around the block. The fat burning benefits that they’ll get from that simple act are huge. 2-Food is more important. 3-Reducing stress is also a key factor. Final message:  “Food and exercise are keys. And it’s really, really simple. Just don’t eat junk food, and take it easy out there.”
